newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.AFRICAN FINANCE COMMISSION SEES SPENDING CUTS.
newsitem.headline: S.AFRICAN FINANCE COMMISSION SEES SPENDING CUTS.

text.p: South African spending on a range of items would have to drop 4.7 percent in real terms in 1997/98 partly because of over-ambitious budget deficit targets, the country's Financial and Fiscal Commission (FFC) said on Wednesay.
FFC director Pundy Pillay, addressing a parliamentary finance and public accounts committee, also criticised government agencies for hiding financial data.
He said his estimates on government revenue and spending were based on calculations made by the commission, which is mandated to decide how national spending is split between the provinces.
Pillay said the FFC predicted total tax revenue and borrowings would decline 1.4 percent on 1996/97 figures.
He said 33 percent of total government expenditure of about 185 billion rand would be swallowed up by items like debt servicing and improved pay and conditions for the civil service.
What was left would be split between national spending and provincial spending, but the size of the 33 percent "top slice" meant these budgets would suffer.

"Our figures show that excluding the top slice, national and provincial spending together will have to decline 4.7 percent in real terms," Pillay said. "National spending will drop 17 percent in real terms and provincial spending will decline 6.7 percnt."
This had serious implications for such programmes as defence, the provision of running water to deprived communities, education, health services and the fight against crime, Pillay said.
He said it was extremely difficult to obtain spending figures from the government.

"It seems to be a case of not wanting people to know, there is a lack of transparency," Pillay said. "I can't emphasise enough how hard it is to work with a state agency that is either incompetent or obstructive, or both."
He said there was a lack of clarity about plans to improve conditions in the civil service.
"This was to have been paid for out of the downsizing of the public service. The service hasn't been downsized, but wages have increased anyway," Pillay said.
He said the FFC objected to the speed at which the government's macro-economic strategy, unveiled in June, planned to reduce the budget deficit.
"You have to slow it down. We think the deficit should be cut by half a percentage point per annum," Pillay said.
